hedline.hl1: To Rid Our Roads of Sport Utilities

abstract.p: Letter from Paul Wright on William C Ford Jr's admission that utility vehicles are dangerous but are Ford's best sellers; says obsessive preoccupation with share prices distracts even those corporate managers with best of intentions from developing new strategies

block.p: William C. Ford Jr., the chairman of Ford Motor Company, said a mouthful when he noted the dilemma for companies like Ford that try to take long-term, environmentally friendly actions, which get scrutinized by Wall Street analysts ''focused on the next quarter's report'' (front page, May 12).

William C. Ford Jr., the chairman of Ford Motor Company, said a mouthful when he noted the dilemma for companies like Ford that try to take long-term, environmentally friendly actions, which get scrutinized by Wall Street analysts ''focused on the next quarter's report'' (front page, May 12).

The obsessive preoccupation with share prices is distracting even corporate managers with the best of intentions from developing the kind of strategies we desperately need to think far into the future.

With our political leaders refusing to talk seriously with us about truly long-term issues, and with share analysts hampering the efforts of our brightest executives to do so, we seem incapable of considering our obligations to future generations.
